Vehicle Safety
Always use turn signals.
Don’t get distracted by using your cell phone.
Check mirrors and blind spots.
Look before you open your car door.
Stay out of bike lanes.
Pass bicyclists slowly.
Give bicyclists at least 4 feet when passing.
Allow bicyclists the entire lane if necessary.
Personal Safety
Always be alert and aware of your surroundings and the people around you.
Refrain from listening to music or wearing headphones while riding the transit system.(iPods and cell phones will distract you and could make you a potential target)
lf you are attacked, scream or blow a whistle in order to bring attention to your situation.
Bus Safety
Stand near others and in well-lighted areas, move to your bus as it arrives.
During off hours, ride as near the bus driver as possible.
lf trouble occurs, notify the bus driver. The bus driver can radio into his/her dispatcher, who can then notify the MBTA Transit Police Department.
Train Safety
When waiting for a train, stay in a central location that is occupied by other patrons (it\'s true that there is safety in numbers).
During off hours, ride as close to the train operator as possible.
lf someone bothers you, move to another seat or car and notify the train operator.
lf you are on a platform or inside a station, you may use the Police Call Box to notify the Transit Police.
If you are on a train, train operators can be contacted by using the intercom at each end of every train car.
Bicycle - Traffic Principles
Always use hand signals to let people know you plan to stop or turn.
Ride on the right side of the road.
Always ride with the flow of traffic.
You must give pedestrians the right of way.
Make eye contact with motorist to make them aware of your presence.
Bicycle - Gear Basics
Pump tires up regularly and replace them when they are worn.
Use a high-security U-lock to secure wheels
Always wear a helmet while riding your bike no matter what.
Wear bright or reflective clothing.
Lights are mandatory at night, white in front and red for the rear.

string-array.name: random_tips
string-array.item: In 2005, public transportation saved the U.S. 6.9 million tons of CO2 emissions.
Save a few pounds of CO2 by sharing a ride with your neighbors or coworkers.
Consider going carless and biking to work!
Hybrids and electric vehicles have better gas mileage and run cleaner than their counterparts.
Keeping your tires properly inflated can save an estimated 2 billion gallons of gas each year.
Adhering to the speed limit and avoiding sudden starts and stops will help you burn less gas and bump up your MPG.
Cleaning your air filter regularly can improve your gas mileage significantly.
Speeding, rapid acceleration, and hard braking are not only unsafe; they lower your gas mileage.
Using your cruise control will keep you driving at a more consistent speed and can generally improve fuel efficiency.
Idling wastes fuel. It’s more efficient to turn the car off and restart when you are ready to go.
Driving around with heavy objects in your trunk? Leave them at home and save some fuel.
A tune-up could make a considerable improvement in your miles per gallon.
Travelling on off-peak days can prevent you hitting congested highways and wasting gas.
